tit.cmt: 他の用語と統一するためarchitectureをstyleに

sen.j: 主殿造（しゅでんづくり）は、室町時代の武家住宅の様式として建築史で提唱された言葉である。
sen.e: Shuden-zukuri architecture is the term proposed for indicating the architecture of samrai resedences in the muromachi period in the architectural history.
Shuden-zukuri architecture is the term proposed for indicating the architecture of samurai residences in the Muromachi period in architectural history.
Shuden-zukuri style is the term proposed in architectural history for indicating the architectural style of samurai residences during the Muromachi period.
sen.cmt: FBに従って修正しました。

sen.j: 武家住宅も初期は寝殿造の系統であり、足利義教の将軍邸（花の御所）も寝殿を中心にした配置を取っていた。
sen.e: Initial samrai residences also followed the Shinden-zukuri style, and the layout of Shogun Yoshinori ASHIKAGA's residence (Hana no Gosho (literally, Flower Palace)) was also centered on a shinden (main house).

Initial samurai residences also followed the Shinden-zukuri style, and the layout of the Shogun Yoshinori ASHIKAGA's residence (Hana no Gosho [literally, Flower Palace]) was also centered on a shinden (main house).

Initially, samurai residences followed the Shinden-zukuri style, and the layout of the Shogun Yoshinori ASHIKAGA's residence (Hana no Gosho (literally, Flower Palace)) is centered on a shinden (main house).
sen.cmt: FBに従って修正しました。アポスﾄロフィを修正

sen.j: それが足利義政の東山殿になると、主殿と呼ばれる常御所が造られた。
sen.e: However, in Yoshimasa ASHIKAGA's Higashiyama-dono, Tsune no gosho called a shuden was created.
However, in Yoshimasa ASHIKAGA's Higashiyama-dono Tsune no gosho called the Shuden was created.
However, by the time of Yoshimasa ASHIKAGA's Higashiyama-dono, a Tsune no gosho (a building for living) called the Shuden was created.
sen.cmt: FBに従って修正しました。アポスﾄロフィを修正

sen.j: 主殿には対面や仏事を行う部屋、寝室などがあり、一つの完結した生活の場となっていた。
sen.e: In a shuden, a room for taimen (confirming the relation between master and servant each other), a room for conducting Buddhist services and bed rooms were placed, making it a place where all daily activities could be done.

In the Shuden, a room for taimen (meeting to confirm the relations between master and servant), a room for conducting Buddhist services and bedrooms were created, making it a place where all daily activities could be done.
The Shuden was a place where all daily activities could be done with a room for conducting taimen (meeting to confirm the relations between lord and retainer) and Buddhist services and bedroom.
sen.cmt: FBに従って修正しました。

sen.j: この形式は、渡り廊下で寝殿と対屋をつなぐ寝殿造や、玄関・大書院・小書院などを連ねる書院造とも異なっている。
sen.e: This architecture is different from that of the Shinden-zukuri style where a shinden and Tainoya was connected with a connecting corridor or from the Shoin-zukuri style where an entrance, a dai-shoin (a large drawing room) and a sho-shoin (a lsmall drawing room) were connected in a row, and is sometimes called "Shuden-zukuri architecture" saying that it constitutes an independent archtecture.

This architecture is different from that of the Shinden-zukuri style, where a shinden and Tainoya were connected with a corridor, and from the Shoin-zukuri style where an entrance, a dai-shoin (a large drawing room) and a sho-shoin (a small drawing room) were connected in a row. This architecture is sometimes called Shuden-zukuri architecture--the implication being that it constitutes an independent archtecture.

This architectural style is different from that of the Shinden-zukuri style, where a shinden and Tainoya (the building where family members of the residence lived) were connected with a corridor, and the Shoin-zukuri style where an entrance, a dai-shoin (a large drawing room) and a sho-shoin (a small drawing room) were connected in a row.
sen.cmt: FBに従って修正しました。

sen.j: 一つの独立した様式であるとして「主殿造」と呼ぶことがある。
sen.e: It is considered as a distinct architectural style and called the Shuden-zukuri style.
sen.cmt: FBに従って修正しました。

sen.j: （参照：平井聖「日本住宅の歴史」）
sen.e: (Refer to "Housing history in Japan" by Kiyoshi HIRAI.)
(Source: Housing History in Japan, Kiyoshi HIRAI.)
(Source: Housing History in Japan, Kiyoshi HIRAI.)

sen.j: 当時の主殿造の建築遺構は残っておらず、文献類から様子が知られるのみ。
sen.e: No building with Shuden-zukuri architecture remains and its natures can be supposed only from the available documents concerned.
There are no extant buildings with Shuden-zukuri architecture; its characteristics can only be surmised from existing related documents.
No buildings of the Shuden-zukuri style have survived from that time and its characteristics can only be surmised from existing related documents.
sen.cmt: FBに従って修正しました。

sen.j: 時代は下がるが、園城寺にある書院は、主殿造の様式を残していると言われる。
sen.e: Although in a later period, it is said that the shoin in Onjo-ji Temple keeps some aspects of the Shuden-zukuri architecture
Although in a later period, it is said that the shoin in Onjo-ji Temple maintains some aspects of the Shuden-zukuri architecture.
Although built more recently, it is said that the shoin (drawing room) at Onjo-ji Temple maintains some aspects of the Shuden-zukuri style.
sen.cmt: FBに従って修正しました。

sen.j: 床、棚、書院を備えており、古風な書院といった印象を受ける。
sen.e: Provided with floors, shelves and a shoin, it gives the impression of an old-fashined shoin.
Provided with floors, shelves and a shoin, it gives the impression of an old-fashined shoin.
The floor, shelves and shoin give an impression of an old-fashioned shoin.
sen.cmt: FBに従って修正しました。

sen.j: 園城寺の勧学院客殿（1600年）、光浄院客殿（1601年）は国宝。
sen.e: The Reception Hall of Kangakuin (built in 1601) and Reception Hall of Kojoin (built in 1601) in Onjo-ji Temple are national treasures.
The Reception Hall of Kangakuin (built in 1601) and Reception Hall of Kojoin (built in 1601) in Onjo-ji Temple are national treasures.
The Reception Hall of Kangakuin (built in 1600) and Reception Hall of Kojoin (built in 1601) at Onjo-ji Temple are National Treasures.
sen.cmt: FBに従って修正しました。

sen.j: また、園城寺の日光院にあった書院は東京に移築され護国寺月光殿になっている（重要文化財）。
sen.e: The shoin placed once in Nikko-in Temple of Onjo-ji Temple was dismantled and reconstructed in Tokyo, becoming Gekko-den (literally, a moon light hall) at Gokoku-ji Temple.
The shoin placed once in Nikko-in Temple of Onjo-ji Temple was dismantled and reconstructed in Tokyo, becoming Gekko-den (literally, a moon light hall) at Gokoku-ji Temple.

The shoin that was once in Nikko-in of Onjo-ji Temple was dismantled and reconstructed in Tokyoto become the Gekko-den (literally, a moon light hall) at Gokoku-ji Temple (Important Cultural Property).
sen.cmt: FBに従って修正しました。
